Description: Terracotta mould-made female figure wearing a ribbed kalathos (polos). White coating with red-brown paint preserved on some areas of hair. Light brown-pink fabric with grey core. Common fine mica, quartz and rare white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Woman wearing polos (Hera?), consistent with, but not identical to (as this is a local verion of) seated or standing figuines dating from the mid/late 6th to the 5th century BC across the Greek world, in (but not exclusively) Rhodes, Cyrenaica, Sicily, Boeotia, Attica and Halicarnassus (Higgins 1954, nos 208,293,329, 646, 650, 1426, 1429). Parallel wearing ribbed kalathos from Sanctuary of Artemis Paralia, Cyprus (GR 1866,0101.179 ). '11' is written on back in pencil. Probably locally made, though some East Greek fabrics are similar.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.026) (Phase 1)
